ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Some level of live discussion during virtual live lecture.
This was a live virtual lecture, with 15 minutes of seminar style discussion at the end.
N/A
N/A.
N/A
Live virtual lecture.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about various psychopathological diseases during childhood from various lecturers.

I learned a lot about different developmental disorders, as well as the research methods in developmental psychology and how social policies surrounding children with mental disorders and disabilities are developed.
I learned a lot about different developmental disorders, and the current research being done in this field.
A pretty wide swath of topics covered from specific mental illnesses to public policy. Most lectures are taught by guests who are experts in their field.
learned about different disorders for children and treatments
I learned about various mental health problems for children and how to assess and diagnose.
Learned a lot about child development, especially in the gender identity lecture!
abnormal development, physchology, etc.
I learned about a survey of developmental disorders. I also learned how to write a long paper (20-25 pages) which is something that I have never done before.
I learned about the basic and common psychological conditions that affect children from a variety of experts in the field.
A great overview of the many psychopathologies given by experts in the field.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths are guest lecturers and professors. The weakness is the lack of discussion in the class.

The course had a lot of interesting content about children and mental disorders. We often had guest speakers present on different topics, which made learning the content new and interesting every week. However, since it was a lecture, it was not as engaging as it could have been. Breakout rooms could have been used to allow students to converse with each other.

strengths: super interesting material, get to hear a lot of different perspectives from different guest speakers
weaknesses: the course wasn't very structured (which might be a strength for some people, I just prefer structure)

Of course, the core part of this course missing this semester was the practicum component of being able to volunteer with children. I think with that experience, this course would have been greatly enriched. For what it was, it was still pretty engaging, and I really appreciated the diverse range of lecturers that came in.

I think I would have appreciated a little more feedback on the two earlier papers we turned in, as well as a bit more continuity from week to week in terms of topics and flow of class.

I thought the professors did a good job of keeping the course as engaging as possible given the circumstances, but it definitely felt lacking without the opportunity to volunteer and participate in live, in-person discussions. All the guest lecturers were very knowledgeable though, as were Fred, Eli, and Dennis!

the material is very interesting, but it could use a bit more structure, especially over Zoom. also, in the online format, I feel like it could have used more outside work besides the paper we had to write and some readings, such as additional reading responses or something of the like to make it feel a bit more organized
Fascinating information and guest lecturers were brought in. I really enjoyed going to the lectures! Z
I think having experts come in to teach the topics was really interesting. The class could be better by including more discussions.

i came into the course with high expectations but feel like i didn't get much out of the biweekly lectures. maybe it's because it's an advanced seminar, but it would've been great to have had a quick recap of what each disorder was before a guest speaker lectured on it, or a final lecture that talked about psychopathology as a whole that tied together all the guest lectures we had this semester (i.e. what does the field look like today?) i don't know. 

also, the final paper felt kind of out of the blue and really overwhelming. the final paper was basically self-work, without much application from what we learned in the course itself.

Strengths: covers a wide range of topics 
Weaknesses: couldve had more discussion between the students in the class
excellent coverage of nuanced topics and great guest speakers

Strengths: great lecturers 

Weaknesses: not enough discussion, do not know how you are doing in the class
The style of lecture is different from any other class I've taken before. There are three main professors for the course, but many of the lectures are taught by guest speakers.

It is hard to evaluate the course for this semester because it would usually contain a component where students get positions working with children, and that was not possible this semester. I think that this component would have been a great addition to the class and a good way to apply knowledge.

I think the strength is the professor. I really liked his lectures the most and they kept me attentive.

The weakness was the lack of discussion. Going in, I thought that the course was going to be discussion-based and it was just another lecture course. There was not a lot of time to discuss with the professor or with other students about ideas or experiences. It was also a bummer that due to covid, we couldn't do the volunteer portion of the class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The professors were very accomodating with the assignments and readings. Even though the classes were synchronous, the slides were posted after every class, which was very helpful. Because of the virtual format, it was not as engaging as an in-person class, but I still learned a lot about the content.

I definitely think more regular engagement would have been helpful  both as live discussion during class (perhaps with some discussion questions) and/or maybe some kind of offline engagement, such as through a discussion board on Canvas. We could even pose particular questions before each lecture that we specifically are curious about learning prior to each lecturer coming in.
If more thought could have been put into how to facilitate engaging discussions, that would have been nice.
asking questions is always more awkward over zoom, so more structured class engagement/discussion could have worked well
I think adding more student-led discussions and maybe some interactive projects would help make the online course more engaging.
I recommend more pre-recorded content to supplement guest speakers and lectures
I liked the classes where there were powerpoints -- it was harder to follow classes when there weren't presentations
I thought this was an amazing course. The only thing that might make it better is having a bit more guidance on the final paper.
Recording the lectures would be very helpful in the future
The engagement in virtual lectures could be improved, such as through polls and more discussion.
I think that virtual engagement could have been enhanced by discussion. It was hard to focus for an hour and fifteen minutes with no pause for digestion.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, definately. Especially if it is in person.

I would definitely recommend this course to other students. The content and readings are very interesting and the professors were great. I had no experience with developmental psychology, but I still learned a lot in this class.
I would recommend if you're interested in the topic. The lectures were super interesting and I learned a lot of new information. I wouldn't recommend if you need to have structure.
I would recommend this course to another student particularly in a semester in which the practicum/child-volunteer experience is reinstated post-COVID.
During a COVID-free year, definitely! If it's only offered online... maybe look for courses that are better suited for Zoom.
Yes
I would recommend it for the material, but it seems like the class is much better and students get a lot more opportunities when it is in person
Yes, the lectures are fascinating and all of the information is, I feel, really vital going forward in our evolving world.
Yes, this was a great introductory course into child psychology.
Yes! If youre interested in child mental health and want a seminar whose work is concentrated at the end of the semester, take it!
Yes
Yes! It is an amazing course! However, you do have to be self-motivated to learn as there are no other assignments throughout the semester to facilitate and reinforce material from lecture.

I would recommend this course to students when everything is back in person because I think the material is highly interesting but it could be great to have the application aspect of engaging with children as well.
Yes, especially when the volunteer opportunity is reintroduced. The ability to work with Professor Volkmar is worth it.
